ResponsesInList.Title: students list of ungraded attempt quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: Sometimes I allow a quiz to be submitted after the deadline has passed using the User Exceptions tool. Or I allow other students to try to improve their grades on a quiz by giving them extra attempts. At the same time, all students have another new quiz to answer because classes are moving forward and time does not stand still. All teachers have many students. This usually means that after a while I've forgotten which students have ungraded tests or which ones I haven't reviewed yet. Then, to fix this I have to go through each quiz, one by one, to check that all my students have all their attempts graded. This involves a lot of time. I think it will be useful to have a tool that shows us a list of all the students who have an ungraded attempt without having to buy each quiz one by one. Does anyone know if moodle has a tool or tip that allows you to do this? Thank you so much

ResponsesInList.Title: Re:  students list of ungraded attempt quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: If your quiz has any essay question, (you could add a simple essay question yourself) in the quiz, the Grade Me plugin will show every student who needs a quiz, "graded."

ResponsesInList.Title: Re:  students list of ungraded attempt quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you very much

ResponsesInList.Title: Re:  students list of ungraded attempt quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: As Al noticed, you are using essay questions. Right? If so, Al's suggestion seems viable, but I don't personally use it. I would first look at the grade book to see which quizzes have students with no grade for a quiz. It might be that for some quizzes every student has a grade. Then using the Gradebook, I would go to those quizzes with ungraded quizzes. From the Grades view, I can see which students require grading. As a suggestion, consider not allowing students to submit late. Make do dates be solid! I know, I know, I know. But train students to do work on time, then you will minimize the number of exceptions. Also, there might be ways to convert essay questions into other automatically graded types, such as T/F, Multiple Choice, etc. Then you would not need to grade these. This is especially important for multiple attempts. Multiple attempts with quizzes containing essay questions can develop into a grading nightmare.

```text

Is there some way for the future quiz scores to count as empty, rather than hidden?

ResponsesInList.Title: How can I make a quiz with penalty grades for wrong answers

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I make a quiz with penalty grades for wrong answers
ResponsesInList.Text: According to the documentation for the Multiple Choice question type ↗ : "With multiple-answer Multiple Choice questions, each answer (choice) may carry a positive or negative grade. If the total grade is negative then the mark for this question will be zero." "With single-answer Multiple Choice questions, you can specify negative or non-negative grades for each answer. A single-answer Multiple Choice question can result in a negative mark if its behaviour is set to Deferred feedback, but not other modes (Adaptive mode, Interactive with multiple tries, etc.)..." If you have more than one question in a quiz, the total mark is the algebraic sum of the marks for each question. So if you have a negative mark for a "single-answer Multiple Choice question in a quiz with Deferrred Fedback behaviour", this negative mark will be subtracted from the marks for the other questions. However, if the total mark for the quiz is negative, the grade in the gradebook will be zero. There might be other question types that accept negative marks, but I don't know about them. Also, I don't think there can ever be any negative grades in the gradebook.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Organizing quiz categories
ResponsesInList.Text: Some of this organization depends upon what you are planning to use in a quiz within a course. First, I like to create categories for my courses, such as Business, Engineering, etc.  My thoughts are that Business courses might share questions from Business textbooks, so question banks created under the Business category can be shared by other Business courses. Then, for a course, such as Statistics, I make another question bank category for "statistics."  Then, under this category, I create separate categories for different chapters, such as "Ch01-Introduction," "Ch02-Descriptive Statistics," etc.  Finally, I put the textbooks question banks under these.  Yes, I might have more than one textbook's question banks under one chapter. When I create a quiz for Ch01-Introduction, I tell the quiz to pull questions from the "Ch01-introduction" group and "subcategories."  Using this approach, if I decide to add more questions, such as textbook #3 questions, I can keep these in their own group, under Ch01-Introduction, and the Moodle quiz can pull from all three resources.  You can even add another category under Ch01-Introduction titled something like "My own created questions." But a lot of this, once again, depends on how you plan to use your questions.  I run my own small Moodle, and don't have to worry about other teachers, so I can do whatever I think is best for ME. So, just as a suggestion, an alternative solution for you would be something like: System | Course_Category | Category_Topic1 Chapter 1 Book1 -MC() Chapter 1 Book1 -FIB() Chapter 1 Book1 -Match() Chapter 1 Book2 -MC() Chapter 1 Book2 -FIB() Chapter 1 Book2 -Match() Category_Topic2 Chapter 2 Book1 -MC() Chapter 2 Book1 -FIB() Chapter 2 Book1 -Match() Chapter 2 Book2 -MC() Chapter 2 Book2 -FIB() Chapter 2 Book2 -Match() This assumes that you might want to create a quiz for Chapter 1 that might include randomly selected questions from all groups under the Category_Topic. I also don't know if the two textbooks, in your example, parallel each other, but I think that you get the idea. Another advantage of this approach is that it gives you the easy ability to remove old textbook question banks and add new, without the need to do anything at the "edit quiz" level.  Pretty powerful stuff.  Moodle is the only major LMS with this much power in its quiz engine.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I can see other teacher's categories
ResponsesInList.Text: It's because some teachers have published their question categories. This problem results from misunderstanding of what it means to publish a category. Some people seem to think publishing a category means making it available for quizzes in their own course. In fact, it means publishing a category all over the site for all the teachers to see and to use. We've had this problem on our site, too - several of our teachers inadvertently published their categories which resulted in some confusion (just in your case). If you are an admin of your site, you can easily track down those "public" categories in the database - search the mdl_quiz_categories table for any records with publish set to 1 . You will then see which courses they come from and you will be able to contact the teachers of those courses and ask if they really wanted to share their questions with all the other teachers on the site. Hope this helps, Przemek

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I can see other teacher's categories
ResponsesInList.Text: How to see if the bug is already reported: Go to http://moodle.org/bugs/ and log in. (I can't remember if it is the same logins as moodle.org or not. You may have to create a new account.) Click on Query Issues from the link on the left. Click advanced query page at the top. Type an appropriate keyword into the Title of bug box. Click Submit query, then scan down the list of bugs. Repeat 4-5 for some other plausible keywords. If you can't find the issue already reported, then you need to file the new bug. You do that by starting with the Add a new Issue link from the menu on the left. The bug is much more likely to get fixed in you write a good bug report. The mozilla project has some excellent guidelines for writing good bug reports: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/page.cgi?id=bug-writing.html Obviously a few bits of this are not relevant, but most of it is. The key points are: Make it very clear to me what I need to do to reproduce the bug on my server . If I can't reproduce it, I can't fix it. The kind of detailed steps I gave at the start of this message for searching is the level of detail I would expect. Say exactly what you saw that is wrong. Copy and paste any error message. Screenshots are also good. Say what you think should have happened instead. That is, explain why you think what you saw is wrong. Write a summary which is short, but which says exactly what the problem is. (This is hard, do your best.) File this sort of bug under either Questions or Quiz component. Try to guess which of the two is more appropriate, but it is not that important. They all come to me. I think this is a good example of a bug report: http://moodle.org/bugs/bug.php?op=show&bugid=5688

ResponsesInList.Title: Allow some students to review their quiz responses  but not others
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle 3 Hi all, Is it possible to allow only certain students to review their quiz responses and not others?  I wish to allow those students that have failed the quiz the opportunity to review their quiz, but not those students who have passed.  I presume that restrictions set  on the quiz settings page refers to restrictions imposed on  undertaking the quiz but not to review.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Allow some students to review their quiz responses  but not others
ResponsesInList.Text: Suppose your quiz is called 'Quiz A'. In the quiz settings: Common module settings --> ID number: 'quizA'. In the gradebook setup: Add a grade item named 'Quiz A w/o review' with calculation =[ [quizA] ] (no space between brackets) . In the quiz settings: Timing --> Close the quiz: closing time ☑ Enable. Review options --> During the attempt: ☑ Enable all or some Immediately after the attempt: ☐ Uncheck all Later, while the quiz is still open: ☐ Uncheck all After the quiz is closed: ☑ Enable all or some Restrict access --> Access restrictions: Student [must] match [any] of the following Grade: Quiz A w/o review ☑ must be < pass/fail grade or Student [must not] match the following Grade: Quiz A w/o review ☐ must be ≥ leave blank ☐ must be < leave blank Results Until the closing time of the quiz, no student can review his quiz. After the closing time of the quiz, students whose mark is lower than the pass/fail grade can review their quiz and students whose mark is higher than the pass/fail mark can not access their quiz for review. Note In the gradebook, set the weight of 'Quiz A' to zero and set the weight of 'Quiz A w/o review' to the desired value.

ResponsesInList.Title: Importing categories from one class to another
ResponsesInList.Text: I was wondering if there's a way to import question categories (not quizzes) from one course to another? What I would like to do is simply copy the test bank questions I've loaded into one course and put into categories and transfer those to another course. It seems that Moodle will only allow me to copy quizzes from one course to another, which won't work if instructors decide to cover some different chapters, or combine chapters etc.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing categories from one class to another
ResponsesInList.Text: Don't copy your questions. Share them! Moodle 1.9 introduced the notion of question context , allowing questions to be shared at the course category and system level. Sharing is controlled by permissions. So, for example, one group of users might be able to create questions in the math course category, while other users can only use those questions in quizzes, and still others don't see the questions at all. Read the question context documenation here .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing categories from one class to another
ResponsesInList.Text: I've got to weigh in on this one, John, if you don't mind. I've been part of a group of teachers that has been piloting Moodle over the last half of this year for a district wide launch in the fall. I teach six sections of math, so as you can imagine, I have lot's of reusable questions. As I imported and exported questions to move them from one classfile to another, my questions kept doubling themselves, so that a question category that had 20 questions in it, soon had over 100. The system admins had done all their previous development in 1.8, so when I went looking for a solution to my question duplicating problem, I found the question context feature that John describes, that they hadn't known was added. This is a brilliant feature!! Now, all six of my courses are in a course category called "Mr. Lavery," and I use that category for all my questions now. This allows me to create quizzes in any class using those questions. As an added bonus, I can modify the questions in one centralized location and see those changes reflected throughout all my courses. The one wrinkle we ran into, though, is that of roles. You must have the role of "teacher" in whatever context you are trying to use to be able to create question categories . This took us a couple of tries to find. Hope that helps,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing categories from one class to another
ResponsesInList.Text: You must have the role of "teacher" in whatever context you are trying to use to be able to create question categories. Matt, You don't need the Teacher role in a category context to be able to create questions there. You only need a few question-related permissions. For example, you need moodle/question:add ("Add questions") = Allow in that context to allow you to add questions. By assigning the Teacher role in the Lavery context, you get these permissions, but you get over a hundred other permissions that you don't want or need. Also, you become a Teacher in every course in the category. It's a moot point with a category like Lavery, since all the courses in the category are Matt's anyway. But if the category was say Math Dept, then assigning Matt the Teacher role there would have all sorts of unwanted side-effects (like making Matt a Teacher in all math department courses). So you want to create a new simple role with only the question-related permissions allowed and all others Not set, and assign this role to Matt in the Lavery context. Better still, design a collection of simple roles containing different sets of permissions. Role for question creators, a role for question Quality assurance, a role for question users, etc. Now suppose Matt has been assigned the Question creator role in the Lavery context. If Matt is inside one of his six math courses, where he has been assigned the role of Teacher, the category dropdown menu in the Question bank will have a Category: Lavery heading (the context), and under that all of question categories (algebra, geometry, etc.). Matt will be able to add questions to the category. This ability comes from Question creator role assigned above, not from Teacher.

ResponsesInList.Title: What I plan to do to attempt.php
ResponsesInList.Text: I am about to do a major refactor of mod/quiz/attempt.php, and before I started, I thought I would post here to make sure I had my plans clear in my head, and to give all of you a chance to stop me if I have overlooked something vital. Why I think there is a problem It all started because I wanted to fix MDL-6368 and MDL-6369 (let question types easily include some CSS and JavaScript ). This caused me to take a long hard look at mod/quiz/attempt.php, and I realised it was a big complicated mess. This makes it difficult to maintain, which leads to bugs. Probably the underlying cause of this mess is that the one file does at least four different things: It checks all the conditions about whether the student can do the quiz (quiz open and close times, delays between attempts, number of attempts allowed, password, IP address, ...) It starts a new attempt, if necessary. It process any data that came from the previous page (if moving between pages of a multi-page quiz, or clicking one of the save/submit buttons). It displays (a page of) the quiz, for the student to enter their answers into. Also, because of 2. and 3. a lot of the time, when you are looking at the quiz attempt page, you are looking at the results of a HTTP POST request, which means that clicking the reload or back button in your browser does weird things. What I am going to do I'm going to split attempt.php into three bits: attempt.php?attemptid=X&page=Y This will just to part 4 above. It will display a single page of the quiz ready for the student to enter their answers. In can only be used to display an attempt, once that attempt has been started. The only checking it will do is to ensure that this attempt belongs to the current user, is still open, that we have not passed the close date, and the time limit has not expired. Instead of checking all the other conditions, we will store in the user's $SESSION a list of attempt ids that have been fully checked. It the student tries to go directly to attempt.php for an attempt that they started in a previous session, it will redirect them to startattempt.php. processattempt.php When you submit the form on attempt.php, it will POST the data to this page. This page just does step 3. above, that is process the responses. Once it has done the processing, it redirects the student pack to attempt.php (or review.php if they did submit all and finish).

In my Word course, we have two tests (set up as "quizzes" in Moodle). ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quizzes being linked?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Nicole, I am a Moodle user like you. I had this kind of problem until I understood the following: quizzes and questions are distinct entities. Quizzes are shells in which questions are placed. Here is how a problem can occur: You make Quizz01 that includes question A. Then you make a copy, Quizz02, and edit it. Heck! Everything is mixed up! Here is what happens: Quizz01 contains question A. When you copy Quizz01, you get: Quizz02 which also contains question A. When you edit Quizz02, you are actually editing question A and simultaneously Quizz01 because both Quizz01 and Quizz02 contain the same question A! Remember that when copying a quiz, questions are not copied. Only the references to the 'same' questions are copied. What you should do: Label your questions clearly, e.g. 'Question 1 of Mid-term', 'Question 1 of Final', etc. Check that your quizzes contain the right questions. Be careful when copying quizzes, because you also need to make new questions either from scratch or by copying existing questions.

ResponsesInList.Title: Integrating Zoomify images into quiz module
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, I've been using the zoomify tools to display high resolution images online in some online tests I manage. I've hacked this into the quiz module and thought I would throw it out there in case others could make use of it. Zoomify ( http://zoomify.com ) takes a large, high resolution image and creates a bunch of smaller, lower resolution tiles which are then loaded by the Flash movie as the user zooms in. This means that the individual files loaded are small but the resolution of what can be seen is high. This is great for detailed images that you want a student to be able to view but which would be way too large if you loaded up the full size jpg as one file. I've added some code to the /mod/quiz/locallib.php quiz_print_possible_question_image() function that looks to see if a zoomify file is available and if so, it loads the flash code into the page, if not, it displays the image as normal. I have not extensively tested it and have only tried it using the multiple choice question type so I have no idea what it might look like in other question types but it should be fine. I've attached the source code to this post. Simply replace the existing quiz_print_possible_question_image() function in /mod/quiz/locallib.php to give it a try. You will need to download zoomify, convert an image (works well converting .tif, not sure about other file types), zip up the directory that zoomify creates, upload this to your course, unzip it, create a low resolution .jpg to go along with it, upload that file to the same parent directory as the zip archive (and the new unzipped folder) and add the low resolution jpg to the question as a figure. The zoomify.swf needs to be uploaded to /mod/quiz also. In theory, now when the quiz module looks to display the figure for the question it will find the filename of the low res figure in the database , then check to see if a high res zoomify version is available and if so, it should display it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Integrating Zoomify images into quiz module
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi simon: It looks great!, but a have questions: 1. It's free zoomify? 2. Why is necessary Moock.org?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Integrating Zoomify images into quiz module
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Miguel, Zoomify has a free version (Zoomify EZ) which works very well if you want to take images and individually put them online on a webpage using zoomify as a stand alone flash component. If you want to integrate zoomify with your own flash movies or do more complex server-side integration or have a lot of images to convert then that is when their commercial products come into play. I have only used the EZ version. The moock.org scripts are needed to implement flash plugin detection so that your page can cope if the user doesnt have a flash plug in or has an early version that doesnt handle the zoomify viewer. With plugin detection it will display a message and the lower resolution jpg image rather than having an blank spot on the page with a broken plug-in icon, or similar. This isnt necessary but it is a good way to gracefully cope with the different browser capabilities of your users. Simon.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Awarding Grades to the best X answers from Y Questions
ResponsesInList.Text: I just came across a possible solution to this problem. You can download the quiz responses from the Quiz administration > Results > Responses page as a CSV or Excel file, then use the formula SUMPRODUCT (LARGE( question grades array , {1, 2, 3, ... X})) to get the sum of the best X answers. The YouTube video Sum the Top 5 Values - Excel Formula explains how to use it. Then create an Assignment activity with no file upload requirement as a place to return the computed 'best of' grades to students, Download a grading worksheet from this assignment, and use the Excel function VLOOKUP (or better yet XLOOKUP) to map the computed grades from the from the Quiz results into the assignment grading worksheet, and import them back into Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle2word-template
ResponsesInList.Text: how can we use this plugin for a customize question type? Is there any provision to do changes in the word template.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle2word-template
ResponsesInList.Text: The Moodle2Word template (which I maintain) is fairly easy to update to add a new question type, although it requires a small bit of VBA code to be added for each new type. The custom question type you are targeting will also probably need two small methods to be added to support import and export to Word format, see the All-or-Nothing Multiple Choice Question code for an example. However, the main effort in supporting a new question type is mapping the HTML table elements generated from Word into the corresponding Moodle Question XML elements used in the custom question type in the plugin Microsoft Word File Import/Export (Question Format) . This requires XSLT (rather than PHP) programming knowledge. You can easily see the required XML by exporting a question from Moodle into XML , but then you have to define a Word table structure that incorporates all of the components. If the custom question type is similar to an existing supported type, it is quite easy. But if it isn't then there is much more work involved.

ResponsesInList.Title: Quiz report log ip addresses
ResponsesInList.Text: If the wrong forum, please point me in the right direction... Two students take a quiz, suspicious because same questions correct/incorrect.  Look at the ip addresses and they are exactly the same. My question - does the ip address being exactly the same confirm that the same computer was used for taking the test? Or are there set ups that would present the same ip address? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz report log ip addresses
ResponsesInList.Text: That totally depends on where they are accessing the site from.  It is quite possible for two different computers to use the same ip address.  If they are not on the same network as the Moodle site and are accessing over the Internet but from the same location, chances are that the ip address will be the same.  If they are on the same network as the Moodle and accessing the moodle site internally, then the ip address would most likely be different. However, just because they are on the same computer, does not mean that there was any cheating.  One student would have to log out for the other one to log in. When you are setting up the quiz, you can randomize question and answer order which would stop students sitting next to each other to be able to copy.  However, students are pretty ingenious and could easily be taking screenshots and texting each other pictures of the questions or they could just have taken the quiz together at the same time with no supervision.

ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the reply. ResponsesInList.Title: Roadmap for future question type INDIVIDUAL
ResponsesInList.Text: Today we have the question type RANDOM, with which we can accomplish individual quizes. Especially for numerical questions it could be neat to have another framework for attaching individual parameters of files to questions that use the same question text. This is a feature that my collegue statistics teachers have asked for and together we have come up with a possible model for the solution. As we are dealing with statistics, it comes natural to have individual stuff as individual measurement data on file. Each student gets its own file and then analyzes it according to the question text. For educational reasons it could be a good idea to have the student use the very same data file for a number of questions and quizes. In statistics this gives us the possibility to show the students how the use of different statistical tools end up with different results. We have come up with a specification that contains these key points: As data is to be reused between questions, it should be stored at category level (or simular). When an individual question is created, the individual items are chosen from the individual items that the category offers. The first time a student takes an individual question from the category, he/she will be assigned an individual dataset from that category. Whenever the student later takes another individual question from that category, he/she will reuse the same dataset that was used the first time. An individual dataset will contain a limited number of named items. The names and types of the items are defined by the teacher at category level. Example: The category "Some Category" can have four item definitions for its datasets: "number" as parameter; "bloodpressures" as file; "time for recovery" as file; "age group" as parameter. I intend to have the parameter number as an automatic default, having number=1 for the first dataset, 2 for the second etc. For each dataset the teacher then needs to upload a file 'bloodpressures' and a file 'time for recovery' and set the parameter 'age group'. If the student later gets the dataset item 'age group' for a question, the student will also be bound to always get the items 'bloodpressures', 'time for recovery' and 'number' from this dataset if he/she later have an individual question that uses any of these. My plan is to start by constructing a page for editing datasets (datasets.php). It will be reached from the "Editing quiz" page as shown in the attached example. It will store dataset definitions and datasets in these tables: CREATE TABLE `prefix_quiz_dataset_definitions` ( `id` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment, `category` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL default '0', `name` varchar(255) NOT NULL default '', `type` smallint(6) NOT NULL default '0', PRIMARY KEY  (`id`), KEY `category` (`category`) ) TYPE=MyISAM COMMENT='Options for multianswer questions' CREATE TABLE `prefix_quiz_dataset_items` ( `id` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment, I continue by creating the quesiton type INDIVIDUAL. When editing the question the teacher provide a question text and also pick the relevant dataset items by names. It is thereafter necessary to define the actual question type and the answers for each one of the datasets in the category. It would be useful to use some kind of file import to define these answers. I cannot offer any format for this but I hope others can come with ideas here. When the questions have got their answers they will be ready to use in quizes. I will go ahead with this now. If you wish I can have things checked in as I proceed or have a huge bunch of code submitted when all is done.

ResponsesInList.Title: restoring an attempt sended by mistake

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: restoring an attempt sended by mistake
ResponsesInList.Text: I would do a quiz, user override, and give this student a second attempt. Be careful, depending on how you set up the quiz, the student might see which questions on the first attempt they answered correctly. When giving the student a second attempt, you can decide if you want the highest grade, or average grade to be the student's final grade. You can also delete the first attempt, which then gives this student a new try. Or you can tell the student that the questions answered on the first attempt will be carried forward into the second attempt.  You would have to do this manually. Or, you could tell the student "That's it!  Be more careful on the next quiz."

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How do I do this within Quiz?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Dear Bill If the poems themselves do not need to be shuffled (same as your "sorting"?) then this is achievable. But there is no tiered, shuffling of shuffled sets of questions (containing immovable descriptors). So assuming it is okay that all the students get the same poems in the same order, then.... In between the poems you can then add "random questions" which are placemarkers for questions drawn at random from a specified category. Hence after poem one you would add four random questions from the category of questions "questions about poem one." And after poem two you would add four random questions from the category "questions about poem two". The categories would have to contain four or more questions. If you want the students to be given questions about diffferent poems either drawn at random from a set of poems, or at least in a radom order then (since there is no facility for binding questions together and shuffling them) you would have to put the poem and the question(s) in the same moodle question. This would mean that you would have only one multiple choice question about each poem. But you could also 1) Have a poem followed by four questions as part an essay question. I don't know about these but I guess it provides the students with a box to submit an answer, a bit like an assignment. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible to give a quiz without access to the Internet?
ResponsesInList.Text: Although no trick is fool-proof, I've used this one in the past: Disable DNS resolution on all the classroom PCs, then add a manual "hosts file" entry for the Moodle server. To disable DNS resolution in Linux (and Mac?), you can replace their /etc/resolv.conf with a new copy that looks like this: #give a false domain to search search thisdomainwillneverbefound.dom #use the local workstation to resolve DNS lookups nameserver 127.0.0.1 To specify one site that the use should have access to, add an entry in /etc/hosts similar to this one (with the real internal IP and fully qualified domain name of your Moodle server, of course) : 192.168.1.200 mymoodleserver.mydomain.dom If you have a classroom of similarly named Linux workstations (their names only differ by a number, e.g. "compy-01" thru "compy-50") , these files would be simple to distribute, too. Get your two files (resolv.conf and hosts) setup how you want them in your working directory and then...

Further, with careful planning, you can set up your question so that it randomly gives different versions of the question to each student to help cut down on cheating. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to add embedded shortanswer fields on PDF  /image
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Vera, AL's suggestions are excellent. You can place answer boxes over an image for any question type, but you have to use custom formatting with CSS and JavaScript . It's not difficult but you have to get a bit familiar with the coding langages. For text images, PNG format is more efficient than not JPEG. PDF's are special. You need a reader to display them. You may be able to superimpose answer boxes over a single page PDF, much more difficult, if at all possible, if the PDF has more than one page. Anyway, it would be much easier with a PNG image You raise an interesting question. Can PDF "forms" be displayed and filled in in Moodle? Probably not, but that remains to be checked. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: e-mail mentee/parent on completion
ResponsesInList.Text: The official "Email Notification" code that is being built into version 1.9 of Moodle will send notification emails to any "role" that has the email attributes set in the "role override" section of the quiz or course. If you visit the feature request linked at the top of the docs page previously mentioned, you will find a patch for version 1.9 which will almost run on 1.8 of moodle too. I have not tested as I developed this feature on 1.8 and we created it for 1.9 as the "official" version. So it might be better if you request the patch for version 1.8 that I have here and I can post it in this thread if you like. My 1.8 patch does not take note of groupings. So to notify anyone, you would need to have them as a registered user in Moodle and all in a common role. It is designed to notify supervisors and teachers of all quiz submissions. It does take note of the groupings, but it would be a pain to group by every parent or student so that you can have an email notification to a separate parent for each student.... is possible I guess, but I would not want to administer it. This feature (as is) is more than likely not what the OP wanted if I read it right. Unless he is talking about a small group of parents for a larger group of students and all parents receiving all student notifications (or a different sub-group of students each). Another way of wagging the dog would be if you can control the mailboxes of each student and perhaps duplicate emails with certain subjects. This would also be a bit of a pain in the ..... but could use the "confirmation" feature to the student him/her self and copy to someone in the mailbox processing. This is also messy. Personally I would not do that as it is a maintenance nightmare. Hope this helps Graham

ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, What version of Word/Office are you using? The trouble with Macro-based solutions is complexity. The various MS-Word quiz solutions that have been developed over the years are fragile. This is because a lot changes inside of Office/Word at each release, e.g., new security policies, changes to the document models on which the macros are based, etc. These macro-based solutions are developed by the open-source/Moodle community, and there are inadequate human resources to update them to follow the changes of Office. One possible solution is to install inside a virtual machine (you'll need IT support help to do this) an old version of Word (e.g., Word 2007, Word 2013, etc.) for which the macro-based solution was developed.

ResponsesInList.Text: OK - I have another option that's a little more experimental, but doesn't rely on macros (it's based on the same code as the Macro version, however). Inside the VM with Office 2013 (or if you already have Office 2013 installed in Windows 10 you don't need to use a VM) can you try to install the VSTO version of Word-Moodle-Quiz as a setup.exe using the following instructions at: https://github.com/fuhrmanator/word-moodle-quiz#installation--updates - here's a copy of those instructions: Installation / Updates The solution now is a VSTO (Visual Studio Tools for Office) Document-level customization (in Word). It requires .NET 4.0 as well as some VSTO 2010 files to run. To successfully install this on your Windows machine, follow these steps: In Windows, add `http://profs.etsmtl.ca/` to the "Trusted Sites" zone (do not require https: ). For more information, see how to add sites to zones . In Internet Explorer (I'm not sure it works with other browsers), download and run setup.exe . You should see a warning that the Publisher cannot be verified . This is normal because currently there is no certificate for this tool. However, you can verify that it's indeed From: `http://profs.etsmtl.ca/cfuhrman/MoodleQuestions/MoodleQuestions.vsto` If you don't trust this tool, then do not install it. * Download the customized Word document to start creating your quiz questions. If you have trouble installing with the SETUP.EXE file, you can alternately 1) Uninstall the installation if you installed an older version, and/or 2) try installing the MoodleQuestions.vsto . Note this version comes with no guarantees of its stability. Use at your own risk. Documentation The Document-level Customized version of the tool is not yet documented, but it supports most of the functionality documented by Frankie Kam . With a lot of help from my students, I developed this VSTO version (but haven't touched it much for a few years). I tested it again on my Surface Pro 4 just now with Office 2013 (didn't try in Laptop mode though!) and it's working for me (but I'm not using a VM!). Hope this helps!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz Review, Quiz Restrictions not honored

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: old questions to 1.6 'missing type'
ResponsesInList.Text: The backup XML format changes because new features are added, which require new data to be stored, backed up, and restored. When people implement new features they are supposed to ensure that the old backup format is still supported, but if they forget, then it ca be almost impossible for someone else to recover the situation, because that other person can't be sure exactly what changed. Even if you want to start with a clean 1.6.1, you could still use backup and restore to copy your old messed around with 1.4.x version into a clean install of 1.4.x. Then upgrade that clean install to 1.6.1. Then, if you like, use backup and restore to copy that upgraded site into a completely fresh install of 1.6.1. Or, as someone else suggested, go via a 1.5.x version. There were lots of changes to the quiz between 1.5 and 1.6, so it is pretty miraculous that restoring 1.5 backups into 1.6 works. Expecting 1.4 backups straight into 1.6 is clearly too much to expect. Obvously it would be nice if it worked, but if it doesn't and if there are workarounds, then making it work is not the best use of the limited developer time.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Remedial quizzes.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Graeme, If you use a Lesson activity instead of a quiz, you can do exactly what you are wanting. When setting up answers to questions in the lesson activity, you get to select where you jump to for each possible answer. Correct answers would be set to go to the next information or question page, while each wrong answer can be set to loop back to the same page or another page with an explanation of why the answer was wrong and then go ask the question again. When setting up the lesson, Handling of retakes would need to be set to 'Use maximum' so they could eventually wind up with 100%. There is also a plugin, Content pages, (mod_icontent) that lets you present information and ask questions that allows for re-attempting the question if your initial answer is wrong.

ResponsesInList.Text: Moving to Quiz forum...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: System variables in Formulas question types
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mark, With the formula type question, the setup you describe can be done in just one question instead of 3 separate questions. In other words, you can make one question that requires the student to provide multiple answers. I know I have made some questions that required up to a dozen inputs from a student. As for the USER ID, I am not sure. I know that the Generico filter can get you users first and last names which makes it possible to personalize lots of things in Moodle, but I am not sure about it getting the USER ID. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: System variables in Formulas question types
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Mark, I agree with Al. No, I far as I know, it is not possible to have the same set of randomly generated variables in different Formulas type questions. I do not know how to access system variables, such as User ID, or if it is readily feasible. However, you should consider using the "Parts" in the Formulas type questions. You can have as many parts as you want. Parts can use the global variables and local variables (displayed with 'Show more'). Parts have their own text and feedback, and can
have multiple answers. They can be thought of as different questions sharing the same random variables. Note that parts can only be displayed on the same page and that they share the same [Check] button. If required, the quiz can be attempted during different sessions, with the same set of random variables, by setting the quiz's 'Attempts allowed' to 3 for example, 'Grading method' to Highest grade, 'Each attempt builds on the last' to Yes and the 'How
questions behave' to Adaptive mode which allows students to check one or more answers at a time.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: System variables in Formulas question types
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Mark, Dominique is right, it is not possible to have the same set of randomly generated variables in several questions. But as Dominique pointed out you can have as many parts as you want in one unique formulas question. And I must add that a part is not just an input, a part can have several inputs for instance student can enter all the numbers of a matrix as just the answer to one part of a formulas question. Another advice when the question has several parts is to use the adaptive behaviour because even if the question has one unique "Check" button students can just enter an answer for the first part and use the Check button to test this answer. There will be no penalty for the not yet answered other parts. Also if a student has the same wrong answer to one part for several "Checks" there will not be multiple penalty. You are the first one to ask the ability to access system variables like user ID. Of course it could be done but to be honest I don't think I will be able to find the time to do it. In fact for several months I have not been able to find the time to work on the formulas question type code. My problem is that you can't just say "This afternoon I will work on Formulas", to be productive I need to find some hours during several days to first remind me of the current state of the code, read my notes and my todo list and begin to work, and when something is finished I need to do some tests to verify I have not broken something. This explain why for instance I have not yet been able to work on the feedback problems submitted by Dominique Bauer (Sorry Dominique !). On the contrary I am still working on some Moodle coding smaller tasks that only require a few hours of work, for instance this week I submitted a new feature: export of multichoice questions with Aiken format ( MDL-21904 ) but this is all I can currently do.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: System variables in Formulas question types
ResponsesInList.Text: I might be a little off-target from what Mark is asking, but I do want to add some ideas that might help. If the question is "Can a set of variables, such as x, y, z, be used across a group of questions?" the answer might be yes.  I say this because this is what I am doing with the Calculated Multichoice question type. For example, if one wants to use two randomly, let's say x and y, which might take on the values 4 and 5, and then ask: For a rectangle with sides of 4 and 5, 1) What is it's area?, 2) What is it's perimeter, and 3) What is it's maximum distance between corners?, this can be done.  All questions would use the values 4 and 5. There are a few qualifiers for what I say. 1) Calculated Multichoice doesn't create the random variables on the fly, you create this "set" of randomly generated variables when you create the question. 2) The questions that are going to use the same set must be in the same question category . Also, the Calculated Multichoice question type takes some study, like 8 hours of experimenting, to start appreciating what it can do. (So Jean-Michel, I can appreciate what you are saying about needing a block of time to get back into an issue.) Having said this, I do want to add that I find this Calculated Multichoice question type to be one of the most powerful "Moodle built-in, supported" question type, meaning that it is not an add-in. Well, hope some of this is helpful. (Actually, I am thinking about giving a presentation at one of this year's MoodleMoots on this topic. Might anyone find this useful?)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adaptive mode
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Gareth, I'm sorry for the late reply, I've been busy a bit longer than expected. Adaptive mode itself works well, at least it follows simple logic. Suppose the students have three tries. They get 100% on the first try, 66% on the second, 33% on the third and 0% on all subsequent tries, or 1, 0.66, 0.33 and 0 point for a question worth 1 point. The scoring of the Formulas question depends on how you organize sub-questions. If several sub-questions are in the same part, a zero mark is attributed as soon as one answer is incorrect. It's an all-or-nothing kind of behaviour. If the sub-questions are in different parts, the score awarded is the sum of the scores for each part, which are awarded according to the adaptive mode rule. It is important to tell students to modify their answers only if they intend to immediately check them. For example, if students clear an incorrect answer and click the Check button, they lose a try (say 33%) on that sub-question because an empty answer box is interpreted as an incorrect answer. If the student got, say 5/13 on the first try, then fixed questions so that they would get 10/13, the score became 5.71/13 and not what I would expect 6.7/13. Suppose the penalty is 33% per try, and students have answered all questions and clicked the Check button. If they got 5 correct answers, they will have accumulated 5 points. Note in passing that the accumulated points can never decrease. If they change their answers, click the Check button and have 5 more correct answers, their score will be 5x1 (first try) + 5*0.66 (second try) = 8.33, not 5.71 or 6 ,7. Overall, it works pretty well. Feel free to ask further questions if my answer is not clear.

ResponsesInList.Title: Multiple correct answers in Formulas
ResponsesInList.Text: A question in the addon Formulas asks for the mass of the condensed water. Strictly mathematically, the answer is a negative number (because from the air perspective the mass of water vapour has decreased), but I would like the same positive number to be accepted as well. Is there a way for two different answers, say m and -m, to be accepted as correct in the same input field?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multiple correct answers in Formulas
ResponsesInList.Text: Marko, Yes, there is a simple way. For any given part, given: (Ref: https://dynamiccourseware.org/course/view.php?id=22&section=17#tdm_20200320_2354➚ ) _a : target answers _r : student answers The question automatically calculates the following: _d = diff(_a,_r) : differences between elements of _a and _r _err = sqrt(sum(map("*",_d,_d))) : absolute error _relerr = _err/sqrt(sum(map("*",_a,_a))) : relative error In "Simplified mode", the question suggests the following grading criteria: Relative error     == or <     some specified value, for example 0.01 (i.e. 1%) or

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multiple correct answers in Formulas
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks. In the end what I used was r = map("abs",_r); a = map("abs",_a); d = diff(a, r); err = sqrt(sum(map("*",d,d))); relerr = err/sqrt(sum(map("*",_a,_a)));

```text

ResponsesInList.Title: Quiz Score Breakdown by Category
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello everyone. I asked a while ago about by-category score details for quizzes and saw that many other people wanted this as well. Anyway, I made a quick way to do it that: gives you the option to show the score details to the user for each category in the quiz in the order the category appears in the quiz works with multiple-page quizzes can easily be tweaked in format and content If anyone's interested, give it a try and let me know what you think. It should also work in moodle 1.7, but I have not tested thoroughly in later versions. Hope you don't mind the big post. A zipped pdf of the instructions is attached as well. Adding Question Category Grade Breakdown for Quizzes in Moodle 1.6.2 Add a new column showcategorygrades to the quiz table. This will be used to make the category grade breakdown optional. ALTER TABLE mdl_quiz ADD COLUMN showcategorygrades int2; ALTER TABLE mdl_quiz ALTER COLUMN showcategorygrades SET STORAGE PLAIN; ALTER TABLE mdl_quiz ALTER COLUMN showcategorygrades SET DEFAULT 0; Add the following lines to quiz/config.html html to show the control for toggling the showcategorygrades property when configuring quizzes in your moodle . // SRC: Set the category grade control if it is not set Add the following lines to quiz/mod.html to show the control for toggling the showcategorygrades property when editing a quiz. // SRC: Set the category grade control if it is not set if (!isset($form->showcategorygrades)) { $form->showcategorygrades = $CFG->quiz_showcategorygrades; } … quiz_fix_decimalpoints) { ?> : showcategorygrades, ""); helpbutton("showcategorygrades", get_string("showcategorygrades", "quiz"), "quiz"); ?> Add the following line to lang/en-UTF8/quiz.php. This is the English translation for the control label in the forms you edited in steps 2 and 3. $string [ 'showcategorygrades' ] = 'Show category grades' ; Add the following lines to quiz/review.php. This is what will actually show the category grade breakdown in the quiz report. // SRC: Add categories string for breakdown section label $strcategories = get_string( "categories" , "quiz" ); // SRC: Load all the questions for the category breakdown if report is paginated if (! $showall && $quiz ->showcategorygrades == 1) { $allquizquestionids = quiz_questions_in_quiz( $attempt ->layout); $ sql = "SELECT q.*, i.grade AS maxgrade, i.id AS instance" . " FROM { $CFG->prefix }question q," . " { $CFG->prefix }quiz_question_instances i" . " WHERE i.quiz = ' $quiz->id ' AND q.id = i.question" . " AND q.id IN ( $allquizquestionids )" ; if (! $allquestions = get_records_sql( $sql )) { error( 'No questions found' ); } // Load the question type specific information if (!get_question_options( $allquestions )) { error( 'Could not load question options' ); } // Restore the question sessions to their most recent states // creating new sessions where required if (! $allstates = get_question_states( $allquestions , $quiz , $attempt )) { error( 'Could not restore question sessions' ); } } if ( $showall && $quiz ->showcategorygrades == 1) { $allquestions = $questions ; $allstates = $states ; } … // SRC: Category breakdown if it is enabled. if ( $quiz ->showcategorygrades == 1) { $categorybreakdown = array (); $gradescale = $quiz ->grade/ $quiz ->sumgrades; foreach ( $allquestions as $question ) { if (! isset ( $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category])) { $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category] = array (); $questioncategory = get_record( 'question_categories' , 'id' , $question ->category); $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "categoryname" ] = $questioncategory ->name; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "maxgrade" ] = 0; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "scaledmaxgrade" ] = 0; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "rawgrade" ] = 0; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "scaledrawgrade" ] = 0; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "grade" ] = 0; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "scaledgrade" ] = 0; } $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "maxgrade" ] += $question ->maxgrade; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "scaledmaxgrade" ] += $question ->maxgrade* $gradescale ; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "rawgrade" ] += $allstates [ $question ->id]->raw_grade; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "scaledrawgrade" ] += $allstates [ $question ->id]->raw_grade* $gradescale ; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "grade" ] += $allstates [ $question ->id]->grade; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "scaledgrade" ] += $allstates [ $question ->id]->grade* $gradescale ; } $cattable ->align = array ( "right" , "left" ); foreach ( $categorybreakdown as $catinfo ) { $categorypercentage = round (( $catinfo [ "rawgrade" ]/ $catinfo [ "maxgrade" ])*100,0); $cattable ->data[] = array ( $catinfo [ "categoryname" ], round ( $catinfo [ "scaledgrade" ], $CFG ->quiz_decimalpoints). "/" . round ( $catinfo [ "scaledmaxgrade" ], $CFG ->quiz_decimalpoints). " (" . $categorypercentage . "%)" ); } } … // SRC: Print category breakdown if ( $cattable ) { echo '
' . $strcategories . '
' ; print_table( $cattable ); } Create a new file in \lang\en_utf8\help\quiz named showcategorygrades.html. This is the help file for this setting.

Show Category Grades

If you enable this option, a question category grade breakdown will be displayed on the quiz results page.

Categories will be listed in the order they appear in the quiz.

The intention is to provide students with more detailed feedback regarding their quiz performance.

Steve

ResponsesInList.Title: Duplicating a course with questions saved at the wrong level
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm using Moodle 2.7.1 A teacher has created a new course with about 50 quizzes and over 300 questions. But, she has saved all the questions to the course level question bank. We now want to duplicate the course and the backup and restore files are of course huge. I can move all the questions to a system level question bank.  But if I go to the course, they all still appear to be in the original question bank at course level. In future, we will be careful to add questions from the system level course bank, but is there an easier way to solve this problem now, other than going through and editing every question?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Duplicating a course with questions saved at the wrong level
ResponsesInList.Text: Actually moving the questions to the system level will make the issue worse, not better.  With the current design, when the quiz is included in a course backup it includes the entire question bank up to the system level.  This means that if you move all the questions to the system level, they will now be included in every course backup that has a quiz regardless of whether the questions are used in that course or not. If you want to avoid huge course backups, then keep all your questions at the course level. However, I would also advise you to upgrade as overall Moodle performance has improved greatly and we are not seeing near the issues with backups as we used to.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Published test -- unable to view answers
ResponsesInList.Text: To be precise, you have published a category , not a test. The fact that your colleague cannot edit the category (or the questions in it) is a feature, not a bug. When you publish a category, you make it available to others in read-only mode. If you want others to be able to make changes, then you must give them a copy. The easiest way to do this would be for you to export the category in one of the allowable formats (e.g., GIFT), and give the file to your colleague. Your colleague can then import the file into her category. If she truly cannot see the answers to the questions in your published category, that's a bug. What version of Moodle are you using?

ResponsesInList.Text:
There is not an easy way, but there is a hack. When looking at the quiz editing page, copy and paste the following into the browser's URL field, and press enter. 
```text
javascript
:(function(){var count=133;var opt=document.getElementById('menurandomcount').getElementsByTagName('option')[0];opt.value=count;opt.innerHTML=count;})()
```
 That will magically change the first entry in the dropdown from add 1, to add 133. You can change the count=133 bit to use whatever number you want. This worked for me in Firefox .

The only way I can think of achieving the same result using another workflow, is the following: Instead of building one quiz with several sections containing n multiple choice questions each, you bild several quizzes containing ne multiple choice questions each. (sidemark: the number of questions may differ between quizzes). Each quiz is autograded upon submission. You may then generate a general score of the quizzes in the gradebook weighting the score of each quiz and putting the overall grade manually to 0 if one of the quizzes did not reach the pass grade. To do so you would create a category for the three quizzes which gives you a combined total score of the three quizzes. Best regards, Antonia

ResponsesInList.Title: Should we treat blank answers separately?
ResponsesInList.Text: Suppose you've got a short answer question, and the student types nothing, then clicks 'submit', or 'submit all and finish'. Is that a wrong answer? Obviously, if they leave that as their final answer, they will get 0 marks, but should they be told 'incorrect', or should say something else, like 'No answer given'? And should they be given the wrong-answer feedback (feedback associated with answer '*' in the short-answer case)? And should they have a penalty applied? (Presumbably the answer to that depends on whether they have seen helpful feedback.) At the moment, when you submit a blank answer, if you do it the first time you see the question, the system just redisplays the question with no change, ignoring your submit. If you submit any non-blank answer, then submit a blank answer, you get told 'Incorrect'. That is so inconsistent, it's a bug and I need to make it consistent. Similar considerations apply to other question types, and obviously we should adopt the same approach everywhere.

Currently, I have encouraged teachers to create an "I don't know" or "No response" option but that is not ideal.

ResponsesInList.Title: Where are "random" type questions stored in the database in Moodle 4.x?
ResponsesInList.Text: We recently upgraded from Moodle 3.11 to 4.1, so I'm still getting used to the differences. In 3.x, when we created a random question, it created a new record on the `questions` table where the column `qtype` set to "random." I can still see all the random questions that we created prior to the update on this table. However, I noticed that now, when I create a random question, there's not a new record on the `questions` table. So, where is this being stored now?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where are "random" type questions stored in the database in Moodle 4.x?
ResponsesInList.Text: Actually, in Moodle 3.11, the real information about random questions was stored in the quiz_slots table. The row with qtype set to random in the questions table was a vestigial legacy. In Moodle 4.x, the key information has moved into to question_set_references table. You are looking for rows there with questionarea = 'quiz_slot' and itemid as the quiz_slot.id. The key information is then in the filtercondition column. (Why is this a blob of JSON ? because in the future, the flexibility to make random selections is going to increase a lot - we hope.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where are "random" type questions stored in the database in Moodle 4.x?
ResponsesInList.Text: Tim, thank you! They actually have questionarea = 'slot' and that gets me the info I need. The changes to the quiz engine in 4.x are great, I'm looking forward to see what comes next!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where are "random" type questions stored in the database in Moodle 4.x?
ResponsesInList.Text: I have several questions in my moodle installation and I would like to know which ones are actually used in the various quizzes defined in the various courses how can I write a query that allows me to find the questions that are used in the quizzes also taking into account the quizzes that use random questions? Thank you for your support.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where are "random" type questions stored in the database in Moodle 4.x?
ResponsesInList.Text: That is a non-trivial calculation. The information you need is in the question_set_references table. The data there is in two halves: (usingcontextid, component, questionarea, itemid) says where this set of questions is used. You need onces where component is 'mod_quiz' and questionarea is 'quiz_slot'. Then itemid is the quiz_slots.id. Then, (questionscontextid, filtercondition) tell you which questions are being randomly selected from here. filtercondition is a JSON representation of a possibly complex search. At the moment that can only involves question_categories and tags, but in future, more conditions will be possible.

ResponsesInList.Title: Excessive Growth in mdl_question Table After Upgrading to from 4.4 to 4.5
ResponsesInList.Text: Issue Summary After upgrading from Moodle 4.4.2 to 4.5 , we have encountered an extreme and unexpected increase in the `mdl_question` table size, leading to major performance concerns. Before upgrade : The table contained approximately 400,000 rows . After upgrade : The table has grown beyond 11 million rows in just a week or so . Key concern : The issue seems to occur when creating and duplicating quizzes , even before students attempt them. Observations & Testing We ran controlled tests in both Moodle 4.4 and 4.5 with identical quiz creation steps: Added a quiz with two questions from the question bank (no randomization). Moodle 4.4 : Number of rows does not change. Moodle 4.5 : 60 rows were added to `mdl_question` and related tables. Duplicated the quiz within the same course : Moodle 4.4 : Normal behavior. Moodle 4.5 : The duplication process added 120 more rows . Duplicated the quiz again : This time, the table grew by 240 more rows . It appears that each duplication exponentially increases the number of rows in `mdl_question` . Key Considerations Answering the quiz does not seem to be the trigger— the growth happens upon creation and duplication . The exponential increase in records suggests redundant or unnecessary question entries may be created in the database . We previously had hundreds of thousands of redundant rows before the upgrade, indicating that this issue may have been affecting us even earlier, but it has become much more severe in Moodle 4.5 . `mdl_question_bank_entries` has also grown significantly, mirroring the pattern in `mdl_question` . Questions for the Community Has anyone else observed excessive row creation in `mdl_question` after upgrading to Moodle 4.5? Is this a known bug or a schema change in Moodle 4.5 that affects quiz duplication? Does Moodle 4.5 handle question versioning differently, possibly duplicating questions unnecessarily? Are there safe ways to clean up `mdl_question` without breaking existing quizzes? Have there been changes made to how Moodle duplicates Quiz's? Any insights or recommendations would be greatly appreciated!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Excessive Growth in mdl_question Table After Upgrading to from 4.4 to 4.5

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problem of exporting questions to files
ResponsesInList.Text: Read Tim Hunt's post. None of the category export formats includes images. Backup/restore is the only way to copy both questions and images. However if you insist on using category export/import, you could do it in four steps: (1) export/import the questions (2) zip and download the images from the old site (3) upload and unzip the images on the new site. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: problems after deleting question

If you want to poke around in the database, then student responses and scores are stored in the mdl_question_states table, and for random questions, the answer column starts random123-, where 123 is the id of the question that the student actually saw. ResponsesInList.Title: New table question_attempts
ResponsesInList.Text: This post is probably only of interest to quiz module developers, not to most users. The quiz module often has a need for knowing whether a particular question is in use. For example when you want to delete a question the code first checks whether that question is already being used. If it is it will allow you to hide the question but not to delete it completely because otherwise all the data about student attempts at the question would become inconsistent. Now there is a problem with random questions which in an actual student attempt are replaced randomly by some question from the chosen category. The quiz module code currently has no efficient way of finding out whether a particular question has been chosen randomly in a given quiz. There is a table quiz_question_instances which one might think would do the job but it does only record the random question id, not the id of the questions that was actually used in the various student attempts. So I propose to introduce a new table quiz_question_attempts (later to be recalled just question_attempts once I get the go-ahead for separating questions from quizzes) with fields 'question' and 'attempt' which gets an entry whenever a question is used in a student attempt at a quiz. This table would then make it easy with one database query to discover whether a question is in use.

ResponsesInList.Title: Advice for managing a large question bank? (3000+)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Guys, We've got a large question bank with nearly 3000 questions and growing, organized into a tree of categories at the system context level, and administrating it is now putting quite a strain on our server . I'm looking for advice on if there's a better way to structure our question bank to work more efficiently with Moodle. We provide personalized courses to language students, so rather than one large standardised course that all students follow, each student has their own course to which activities are duplicated. To facilitate this, we're heavy users of the Sharing Cart block. To avoid duplicating the data of every quiz at the course level, our questions are stored under the system context for universal access. However we've now come to a bit of a hurdle, as it seems when you backup a quiz in Moodle, it also backups up every single object in the included questions' context. That means for every quiz we copy into a student's course, Moodle goes through the process of backing up our entire database , bringing the site to its knees. Currently, our question bank is structured a bit like this... Beginners Vocabulary Adults Animals Numbered subcategories containing 6-8 questions each Drinks Numbered subcategories Fruit Numbered subcategories Vegetables etc, etc. ...and so on and so forth. Prepared activities are stored in a similarly structured category of hidden courses, which our teachers then use to copy the desired activities into their students' classrooms. The only "solution" I can think of is to store the questions of our quizzes at the course level context. We'll end with lots of duplicate data & a rapidly growing database, however at least Moodle won't be brought to its knees every time we try to copy a single quiz of just a couple of questions. Can anyone think of a better way to do this? (Related links: How to minimize the question bank when doing backup/restore , [MDL-41924] , [MDL-12403] )

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Advice for managing a large question bank? (3000+)
ResponsesInList.Text: Thinking further, this could be helped by structuring our students' courses in a similar way... Adults Beginners Student A, Beginners 1 Student B, Beginners 1 Intermediate Student A, Intermediate 1 Advanced Kids That could allow at least some question categories to be in the course category's context, saving on some of the duplication at course level. However we'll still need to be careful even at this level of separation, as even these subcategories will be quite large themselves.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Advice for managing a large question bank? (3000+)
ResponsesInList.Text: I also used to have a large system level bank.  I ended up moving all the questions to the course level.  While I do now get duplication of questions, keeping the bank contained has helped in a lot of areas, but primarily in back up and restore which was having all sorts of issues when it tried to import the entire question bank. Also, any changes made to questions are now also contained at the course level instead of affecting anyone else using the questions.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Advice for managing a large question bank? (3000+)
ResponsesInList.Text: Two suggestions: 1. I used to use a single course for quizzes where ALL quizzes were administered. With various restrictions you can limit who can see, administer, and take a quiz. Required a little extra effort on my part to make sure students knew where and how to take a quiz, but really cut down on duplication of effort, duplication of questions, and made course backups much smaller. 2. Do not routinely include questions banks in course backups. As an admin, go to, Site administration > Courses > Backups > General backup defaults, and remove the check mark for, Include question bank. With a centralized question bank, courses do not need to back up the same data.

ResponsesInList.Text: On a different note, perhaps you could consider using the Formulas type question for some of your questions. The parameterization is effective and a single question can replace many if they are actually variations of the same question.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is displaying the quiz questions as images available in MOODLE?
ResponsesInList.Text: Q. Is displaying the quiz questions as images available in MOODLE? If you ask ChatGPT: A. Yes, displaying quiz questions as images is possible in Moodle. Here's how you can do it: First, create the quiz and add the questions as you normally would. Then, instead of typing the question directly into the quiz question field, use an image editor to create an image of the question and save it to your computer. In Moodle, click on the "Edit" button next to the quiz and select "Edit quiz". Click on the "Edit" button next to the question you want to display as an image. In the "Question text" field, click on the image icon (a picture of a tree) to open the file picker. Upload the image of the question from your computer to the file picker. In the "Question text" field, add any additional instructions or text for the question. Click "Save changes" to save the question. Repeat these steps for each question you want to display as an image. When students take the quiz, they will see the image of the question along with any accompanying text or instructions.

ResponsesInList.Title: Sharing is not copying
ResponsesInList.Text: Sharing is defined as the joint use of a resource . If I share my lunch with you, we both eat from the same plate.  If I make you a sandwich just like mine, it is another form of charity, but it's no not sharing. In the same way, "sharing questions" means using the same questions, not copies. On our moodle site, we share questions.  Course #1 has a large question database .  Categories are published so they are visible to all teachers.    Only the editing teachers of course #1 (so far, only the site admin) can add, delete, modify, or re-categorize questions.  Teachers in other courses use these questions to create quizzes for their students.   The teachers see read-only questions in read-only categories.  If a teacher finds a mistake in a question, they report it to the site admin, who fixes it.   The mistake only needs to be fixed once, and the question magically is fixed in every quiz in which it appears. So far, everything works beautifully.  However there are some special quizzes (example: the Final exam), which must be identical in every course.   How can this be guaranteed? I experimented with two possibilities: Create the Final in course #1 and allow teachers to Import it. I can't imagine a worse solution.  First, we would have to make the teachers editing teachers of course #1, which would compromise the security of the question database.  Second, Import copies the questions, not just the quiz.  Furthermore, it copies all the other questions from the same categories, and it creates local categories for these questions. Create the Final in course #1, Backup course #1 with just this quiz, put the backup in a public place, and allow teachers to Restore (adding content to their courses) from the backup. Except that teachers don't need to be made editors in course #1, this solution has all the disadvantages of Import . I fully expected Import and Backup/Restore to copy activities , but until I experimented with them, I had no idea that they would make such deep copies.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Significant figures
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dave, "Numbers starting with 1 should have an additional significant digit" is not a strict rule. However, it is a good way to improve the precision of the numbers. If this rule is not applied, the precision of any number is between 0.1% (for example 99.9 ± 0.1 = 99.9 ± 0.1%) and 1% (for example 100 ± 1 = 100 ± 1%). If the rule is applied, the precision of any number is between 0.05% (for example 199.9 ± 0.1 = 199.9 ± 0.05%) and 0.5% (for example 200 ± 1 = 200 ± 0.5%). Thus, by applying the rule, the precision of the numbers improves from ± 1% or better to ± 0.5% or better.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Significant figures
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Jean-Michel, I'm sorry I missed your post. It would certainly be interesting to add a function to display the numbers with a given number of significant digits. In my humble opinion, the problem is not as simple as it seems. We might want to consider the more general problem of displaying numbers, that is, the number of significant digits but also the number format. We could draw inspiration from the calculators' display, such as HP and other calculators, in scientific notation and engineering notation. The javascript function toPrecision(), or a similar function, can only be a one-size-fits-all solution which has some gaps. I think that if we wanted to do the right thing for the Formulas question, we would have to develop a complete scientific display system and make sure it is the best.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pictures not displaying on a quiz page

I was trawling through all the configuration pages trying to get a feel for all the options available (I had too much time on my hands that day!) and I came across the answer.  Try going to Configuration/Variables and then scroll down till you come to a setting called "slasharguments" which is to do with the way Moodle searches for any uploaded files.  Our default setting was the second one in the pop-down list [file.php/pic.jpg] and we couldn't get pictures to display.  The guidance to the right of the pop-down list solved the problem - I switched the setting to the first option [file.php?file=/pic.jpg] and the problem was solved.] Note: according to the FAQ on "slasharguments" this can lead to problems using relative links within HTML documents. You can link to the FAQ directly from this poting as the word "slasharguments"on this page should be a hyperlink.  This gives details of how to fix the problem at the server side.  We haven't done this yet (as we don't host our Moodle site) but I'll try and remember to let you know if we sort it.  I have to say it was great to see the images appear.  They add hugely to the Moodle experience and the glossary I was working on has been transformed! ResponsesInList.Text: It's that time of year again to renew Respondus Lock-down browser, and I would like to know the pros and cons of using Safe Exam Browser instead.  Here are the drawbacks I see: 1.  Since the code is open-source, it is easier to hack 2.  I heard it can't be used on student-owned computers, but I don't think that's true 3. It looks more complicated to use and setup than Respondus, for everyone involved. I really haven't found an easy to read "this is how you set it up and use it" as the teacher or student. 4. Support for problems would not be as good as Respondus. We had a lot of problems with wifi last year and I don't want to switch to something and have the students have different problems this coming year (hopefully wifi problems are taken care of!).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Safe Exam Browser Pros and Cons
ResponsesInList.Text: Good grief. Do people still believe this myth? http://www.zdnet.com/article/six-open-source-security-myths-debunked-and-eight-real-challenges-to-consider/, https://www.irisns.com/fact-versus-fiction-is-open-source-software-less-secure/ (Google will find more.) SEB can be installed on student computers (also known as BYOD). Read the documentation on their website. This presentation gives a good summary: http://safeexambrowser.org/presentations/HowTo_SEB2.0.pdf Ditto. I have dealt with commercial companies, and I heave dealt with Open Source projects, and I know which generally gives better support. Commercial support sucks. Getting online exams to work with students own computers, and wifi, is definitely still hard, not routine. But, it can be done with either Respondus or SEB. Getting and configuring a particular secure browser is the easy part. The real problems are the same in both cases: How do you make your wifi reliable? How do you support hundreds of students installing some additional software onto their own laptops? Can you find enough rooms with power at each desk?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Max Time Limit for Quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: Have you checked the "sessiontimeout" variable in Admin->Variables page? The quiz time limit cannot exceed this setting, which is site-wide. Set it to a greater value, two hours for example.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New quiz attempt - infinitely loading startattempt
ResponsesInList.Text: From the error message, it I looks like you have installed some add-on, which has added a non-standard column date_started to the quiz_attempts table. (These are the columns that 'should' exist https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/v3.3.2/mod/quiz/db/install.xml#L128 ) That is what is triggering the error in Moodle core.
